Introduction

Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) are a class of compounds that act on the estrogen receptor (ER) with a unique mechanism:  They exhibit tissue-specific estrogen agonist or antagonist activity.  Therefore, SERMs can mimic estrogen in some tissues (eg, bone) while blocking its action in others (eg, breast, endometrium).  This dual nature allows SERMs to be used in the treatment and prevention of various conditions related to estrogen activity.

Mechanism of action



SERMs are nonsteroidal compounds that bind to estrogen receptors (ERÎ± and ERÎ²) and induce a conformational change in the receptor.  This change affects the recruitment of coactivators or corepressors, leading to either activation or inhibition of gene transcription (ie, agonist or antagonist activity).  The different expression of cofactors across tissues largely explains the tissue-specific effects of SERMs.

Commonly used SERMs and indications



The most frequently used SERMs are tamoxifen, raloxifene, clomiphene, and bazedoxifene; the indications for each medication depend on its agonist and antagonist activity (

Tamoxifen



Tamoxifen has antiestrogenic effects at the breast but acts as an agonist at the bone and uterus.  Clinical indications include:



  • Primary prevention of breast cancer in high-risk populations (eg, atypical hyperplasia, age â‰¥35 with history of lobular carcinoma in situ, BRCA2 carriers).
  • Adjuvant endocrine therapy for premenopausal women at low risk for recurrence of hormone receptorâ€“positive breast cancer.
  • Second-line adjuvant endocrine therapy for postmenopausal women unable to use aromatase inhibitor therapy (eg, intolerable adverse effects).

Raloxifene



Raloxifene has estrogen agonist activity on bone while exhibiting estrogen antagonist activity in the breast and endometrial tissue.  Clinical indications include osteoporosis treatment and prevention; this is ideal for breast cancer prevention.  Raloxifen is not used in premenopausal patients and may lead to bone density loss.

Clomiphene



Clomiphene acts as an antagonist at the hypothalamus and uterus, leading to a thin endometrium.  It is an ovulation-induction agent used in the treatment of infertility.  Clomiphene acts as an antagonist at the hypothalamus, causing perceived estrogen deficiency.  The hypothalamus then increases GnRH release, which increases gonadotropin (FSH), leading to multifollicle formation and ovulation (

figure 1
).

Bazedoxifene



Bazedoxifene has estrogenic effects on bone but acts as an antagonist at the uterus.  It is used primarily to treat postmenopausal osteoporosis.  Bazedoxifene is often combined with estrogen to treat vasomotor symptoms but prevents estrogen-induced breast tenderness or withdrawal bleeding from standard menopausal hormone therapy (combined estrogen-progestin).

Adverse effects



SERMs are associated with several adverse effects:



  • Hot flashes:  These are the most common adverse effects because they are thought to cause antiestrogenic effects in the CNS and to cause thermoregulatory dysfunction in the anterior hypothalamus via a mechanism similar to the pathophysiology of menopausal hot flashes.
  • Myalgia:  Myalgia is common with tamoxifen, raloxifene, and bazedoxifene.
  • Venous thromboembolism:  SERMs cause a prothrombotic state and can increase the risk for venous thromboembolism, likely due to increased levels of clotting factors (eg, prothrombin; fibrinogen; factors VII, VIII, and X) and activated protein C resistance.
  • Endometrial hyperplasia/cancer:  Tamoxifen acts as an estrogen agonist in the uterus that can stimulate excessive endometrial proliferation.  Its use is associated with endometrial polyps in premenopausal women, as well as endometrial hyperplasia and cancer in postmenopausal women.  Long-term use (>5 years) is associated with an increased risk for uterine sarcoma, although the absolute risk remains low.

Contraindications



  • Current or prior thromboembolic disorders.
  • Current or prior endometrial cancer (tamoxifen).
  • Pregnancy, lactation.
  • Liver disease.
  • History of breast cancer (bazedoxifene).

Summary



Selective estrogen receptor modulators represent a unique pharmacologic approach to modulating estrogenic activity.  Their tissue-selective action allows for targeted therapy in conditions such as breast cancer and osteoporosis while avoiding some of the systemic risks of hormone replacement.
